Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: Cloud tops are rising quickly, and several pilots await revised climb instructions.
Story: My headset pressed tight against my ears, the hum of radar screens and the clipped voices of pilots filled my world. “Tower, this is Delta 452, requesting climb clearance.” I scanned the monitors—cloud tops were rising fast, and I needed to reroute three planes before the weather closed in. My fingers hovered over the console, ready to issue instructions, when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was my stepdad, right on schedule for our weekly call. I’d promised Mom I’d keep in touch, that I’d check in and ask about her new garden, about his health. I could almost hear her voice: “Don’t forget, it means a lot to us.” But the pilots needed me now, every second counted. My mind split—one part desperate to keep my promise, the other tethered to the radar, responsible for lives in the sky. The phone kept buzzing, the radio crackled with urgency, and I sat frozen, torn between the family that wanted my voice and the pilots who needed my words.
